title: 107_hr3676
content:
The Act titled "Medicare, Medicaid, and MCH Tobacco Use Cessation Promotion Act of 2001" amends the Social Security Act to include coverage for counseling for tobacco cessation under the Medicare program. This includes defining counseling for tobacco cessation as a covered service. The term 'counseling for cessation of tobacco use' includes diagnostic, therapy, and counseling services for individuals using tobacco products, provided by a physician or other authorized healthcare professional. Services must align with clinical practice guidelines and be recognized as effective by the Secretary. The term 'counseling for cessation of tobacco use' includes services aligned with clinical practice guidelines and recognized as effective by the Secretary. Payment and cost-sharing for these services are amended to ensure coverage and affordability for individuals seeking tobacco cessation counseling. The amendments made by this section eliminate deductibles and coinsurance for counseling for cessation of tobacco use in outpatient hospital settings. Effective date for these changes is services furnished on or after January 1 of the first calendar year that begins at least 6 months after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. Coverage of counseling for cessation of tobacco use under the Medicaid program includes eliminating deductibles and coinsurance for outpatient hospital settings. Effective date for these changes is services furnished on or after January 1 of the first calendar year that begins at least 6 months after the date of the enactment of this Act. (a) Medicaid coverage for tobacco use cessation medications is expanded by removing exceptions and requiring coverage of FDA-approved agents for promoting tobacco cessation. 
(b) Counseling for tobacco cessation for pregnant women is mandated under Medicaid, with the removal of cost-sharing for these services. The amendments mandate Medicaid coverage for tobacco cessation medications and counseling for pregnant women, removing cost-sharing for these services. Effective date is January 1 of the first calendar year that begins at least 6 months after the enactment of the Act. The amendment promotes tobacco cessation counseling and medications as part of quality maternal and child health services under the Social Security Act. Effective upon enactment of the Act.
